title: Small Bowel Obstruction
diagnosis_topic: Mechanical obstruction of the small intestine often due to adhesions
setup_script: A 65-year-old woman with a history of prior hysterectomy presents with crampy abdominal pain, vomiting and abdominal distension for 24 hours. She has not passed flatus or stool.

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 120/80 mmHg, HR 95 bpm, RR 20/min, Temp 37.5 C.
Distended abdomen with high-pitched bowel sounds; diffuse tenderness without peritonitis.
Electrolyte imbalances with hypokalemia; WBC 12 K/uL; lactate normal.
Multiple dilated small bowel loops with air-fluid levels; collapsed colon.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident orders CT scan with contrast
dynamic_flow.reply: Transition point in mid-jejunum with collapsed distal bowel; no bowel ischemia or free air.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident keeps patient NPO, places nasogastric tube for decompression and administers IV fluids
dynamic_flow.reply: Nasogastric output is bilious; patient's pain improves.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident monitors closely for signs of strangulation
dynamic_flow.reply: Persistent tachycardia, fever, leukocytosis, increasing pain or lactic acidosis prompt operative intervention.
Most adhesive small bowel obstructions resolve within 24-48 hours; monitor output and electrolytes.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident delays surgery in presence of peritonitis or strangulation
If resident discusses water-soluble contrast study
dynamic_flow.reply: Can be used as diagnostic and therapeutic tool to predict resolution and stimulate motility.
Adhesiolysis with removal of cause of obstruction and resection of non-viable bowel if necessary.
Importance of early presentation if symptoms recur and strategies to prevent adhesion formation.

critical_decision_points: Recognition of small bowel obstruction based on history and imaging
Initial non-operative management with NPO, NG decompression and fluids
Identification of signs of strangulation requiring urgent surgery
Use of contrast studies and timing of operative intervention
Patient counseling on prevention and recurrence
